Award.AwardTitle: RCN: Nitrification, a Bacterial Process at the Interface of the Carbon and Nitrogen Cycles

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration: This grant is to support coordination activities, including meetings, a workshop, a website, and sharing of resources for a network of researchers studying all aspects of nitrification by microorganisms. Nitrification is a bacterial process that involves the transformation of ammonia to nitrate. Along with nitrogen fixation and denitrification, nitrification is one of the major processes contributing to the global nitrogen cycle. Ammonia is formed in soils and surface waters when organic matter is degraded and it is also produced industrially as a fertilizer for crops. The bacteria that carry out nitrification extract energy for growth from ammonia and the byproducts of its degradation. The nitrate that is formed can easily be leached into ground water, thereby making it unfit for human consumption. By influencing the availability of nitrogen for plants, nitrification also influences the carbon cycle. Global warming (through release of nitric and nitrous oxides), water quality, food and fiber production, wastewater treatment and bioremediation are all influenced by nitrification. The genomics revolution is having a tremendous impact on the study of nitrification, while simultaneously creating a need for greater coordination of research efforts in this field. Genome sequences are available for five nitrifiers and three more are in progress. The goal of this Research Coordination Network is to coordinate the next generation of research in this important field. Of paramount importance is linking the physiology, biochemistry and genomics of these bacteria to the processes that they carry out in the environment. This linkage will provide the basis for controlling and exploiting these bacteria in various environments. The work is of significance to crop production, wastewater treatment, bioremediation, and global warming. The participating laboratories will provide active training opportunities for research scientists at all stages in their careers, and will incorporate members of underrepresented groups in science. Materials will be developed to educate K-12 students and teachers about the global nitrogen cycle in general and about nitrification in particular.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nitrification, the oxidation of ammonia to nitrate, is a microbial mediated process that contributes to the biogeochemical N cycle. The study of nitrification nowadays has become ever more cross-disciplinary and collaborative. The RCN through the Nitrification Network coordinated research activities where multiple investigators from around the globe were involved. The RCN provided the structure to organize the activities of researchers in the field of nitrification and implemented three international nitrification meetings (ICoN1, ICoN2 and ICoN3). The RCN helped to disseminate results within and outside the field by publishing numerous peer-reviewed articles and 3 books authored by members of the Nitrification Network. The RCN collected input from the Nitrification Network membership that guided activities of the coordination team, which was comprised of senior project personnel.

Periodic meetings of the Steering Committee and interested members were held. The foci of these meetings were the coordination of joint projects such as the book writing projects, collaborative genome sequencing and annotation, joint journal publications as well as the preparations for the ICoN conferences.

By December 2013 the RCN in nitrification is composed of 182 members from diverse countries (e.g. Australia, Austria, Canada, China, Denmark, Ethiopia, Finland, France, Germany, India, Israel, Japan, Korea, New Zealand, Norway, The Netherlands, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, Spain, Switzerland, Taiwan, Thailand, Vietnam, USA, UK). Contact was established through the web site and members received new developments through an email list server. Members span academia (professors, research associates and graduate students) and industry (researchers).

The broader impacts of this RCN were realized in the services provided to international and local communities. K-12 educators in the USA were provided with resources and activities dealing with the N cycle. Graduate and undergraduate students, from the USA and abroad, gained research experiences and networked with scientists from a range of disciplines and locations. Three international workshops were organized by the RCN for Early Career Investigators (graduate students, post-doctors and beginning assistant professors). A web site made publicly available resources useful to different communities. Culture collections were coordinated and developed for long-term maintenance of microbial collections. Diversity, in all its forms, was enhanced and included international and domestic members.
